title: Acts Chapter 23 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 23 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 23 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 23.

questions.question: What did Paul say about his conscience before God in Acts 23:1?
options: I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day
I have sinned against God and man
I am unworthy before God
I have failed to keep the law of God
questions.correctAnswer: I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day
questions.explanation: Acts 23:1 shows Paul declaring he has lived in good conscience before God until that day.

questions.question: Who commanded that Paul be smitten on the mouth in Acts 23:2?
options: The high priest Ananias
The chief captain
The Pharisees
The Sadducees
questions.correctAnswer: The high priest Ananias
questions.explanation: Acts 23:2 states that the high priest Ananias commanded those standing by to strike Paul on the mouth.

questions.question: What did Paul call the high priest Ananias after being struck, according to Acts 23:3?
options: Thou whited wall
A false prophet
A deceiver
A blasphemer
questions.correctAnswer: Thou whited wall
questions.explanation: In Acts 23:3, Paul calls Ananias a 'whited wall' after being struck.

questions.question: True or False: Paul knew that Ananias was the high priest when he first spoke to him in Acts 23:5.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 23:5 states Paul did not know Ananias was the high priest when he spoke.

questions.question: Which two groups were present in the council that Paul addressed in Acts 23:6?
options: Sadducees and Pharisees
Essenes and Pharisees
Zealots and Sadducees
Scribes and Pharisees
questions.correctAnswer: Sadducees and Pharisees
questions.explanation: Acts 23:6 mentions Paul perceiving the council was divided between Sadducees and Pharisees.

questions.question: What belief caused a dissension between Pharisees and Sadducees according to Acts 23:7-8?
options: Resurrection of the dead
Observance of the law
The coming of the Messiah
The place of worship
questions.correctAnswer: Resurrection of the dead
questions.explanation: Acts 23:7-8 show the dissension was over the belief in resurrection; Pharisees believed, Sadducees did not.

questions.question: What did the Pharisees say about Paul in Acts 23:9?
options: We find no evil in this man
He is guilty of blasphemy
He has broken the law
He is a false prophet
questions.correctAnswer: We find no evil in this man
questions.explanation: Acts 23:9 records Pharisees stating they find no evil in Paul.

questions.question: True or False: The chief captain feared that Paul might be harmed by the council and ordered his soldiers to rescue him in Acts 23:10.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 23:10 describes the chief captain's fear that Paul could be torn apart, so he had soldiers take him away.

questions.question: What did the Lord say to Paul at night in Acts 23:11?
options: Be of good cheer; you must also bear witness at Rome
You will be delivered soon
Pray for your enemies
Your journey will end here
questions.correctAnswer: Be of good cheer; you must also bear witness at Rome
questions.explanation: Acts 23:11 shows the Lord encouraging Paul to be courageous and bear witness in Rome as in Jerusalem.

questions.question: How many Jews bound themselves under a curse to kill Paul as described in Acts 23:13?
options: More than forty
Ten
Fifty
One hundred
questions.correctAnswer: More than forty
questions.explanation: Acts 23:13 states that more than forty Jews made a conspiracy to kill Paul.

questions.question: Who warned Paul about the conspiracy to kill him in Acts 23:16?
options: Paul's sister's son
A Pharisee
A Roman soldier
Ananias
questions.correctAnswer: Paul's sister's son
questions.explanation: Acts 23:16 tells us Paul's sister's son heard of the plot and informed Paul.

questions.question: What did the chief captain do after hearing the warning about the plot against Paul in Acts 23:23?
options: Prepared 200 soldiers, 70 horsemen, and 200 spearmen to escort Paul
Released Paul to the council
Sent Paul to Jerusalem
Ignored the warning
questions.correctAnswer: Prepared 200 soldiers, 70 horsemen, and 200 spearmen to escort Paul
questions.explanation: Acts 23:23 shows the chief captain assembling a large force to safely transport Paul.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Acts 23:26: Claudius Lysias unto the most excellent governor ____ sendeth greeting.
options: Felix
Festus
Herod
Caesar
questions.correctAnswer: Felix
questions.explanation: Acts 23:26 identifies Felix as the governor to whom Claudius Lysias sends a letter.

questions.question: What reason did Claudius Lysias give for rescuing Paul according to his letter in Acts 23:27?
options: He understood that Paul was a Roman citizen
He believed Paul was innocent
He feared the Jews
He wanted to please the governor
questions.correctAnswer: He understood that Paul was a Roman citizen
questions.explanation: Acts 23:27 states Lysias intervened because he knew Paul was a Roman.

questions.question: True or False: According to Acts 23:35, Paul was kept in Herod's judgment hall by the governor's command.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 23:35 confirms that the governor commanded Paul to be kept in Herod's judgment hall.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 23 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 23 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Acts 23, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during difficulties?
options: God stands by His servants and encourages them to be courageous
Troubles mean God has abandoned us
We should depend only on our own strength
Trials are to be avoided at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: God stands by His servants and encourages them to be courageous
questions.explanation: Acts 23:11 shows that the Lord stood by Paul and encouraged him to be of good cheer, illustrating God's presence and support during trials. This encourages believers to trust God even in hardship. See also Acts 23:10 and 23:12-15 on facing opposition with courage.

questions.question: How does Acts 23 teach about humility and respect when Paul initially did not realize the high priest was present?
options: Paul apologized for speaking against the high priest when he realized his mistake
Paul refused to show any respect
Paul ignored the high priest and continued arguing
Paul immediately left the council
questions.correctAnswer: Paul apologized for speaking against the high priest when he realized his mistake
questions.explanation: In Acts 23:5, Paul says he did not know the high priest was present and quotes the law about not speaking evil of rulers, showing humility and respect once he understood. This models the importance of humility and respect for authority.

questions.question: What does Paul's declaration of being a Pharisee and belief in the resurrection teach us about standing firm in our faith?
options: It is important to boldly proclaim your faith and convictions even when facing opposition
We should avoid discussing our beliefs to prevent conflict
Changing beliefs to please others is best
Faith should be kept private
questions.correctAnswer: It is important to boldly proclaim your faith and convictions even when facing opposition
questions.explanation: Acts 23:6-7 shows Paul openly declaring his beliefs, causing a division among his accusers, demonstrating the value of standing firm and witnessing boldly despite opposition. This encourages perseverance and courage in faith.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged by conflicts within the church. What lesson about church life and unity can be drawn from the dissension between Pharisees and Sadducees in Acts 23?
options: Differences in beliefs can cause division, but truth must be upheld with love and respect
Disagreements mean the church should be abandoned
Conflict is always sinful and should be ignored
Avoid discussing theological differences
questions.correctAnswer: Differences in beliefs can cause division, but truth must be upheld with love and respect
questions.explanation: Acts 23:7-9 records a sharp division but also shows the importance of standing for the truth (resurrection) while the Pharisees defended Paul. This teaches believers to handle disagreements carefully, with commitment to truth and charity.

questions.question: How does Acts 23 demonstrate God’s providential protection for His servants facing danger?
options: God orchestrates circumstances to protect His servants, as seen in the warning and military escort for Paul
God leaves believers to face dangers alone
Protection depends solely on human effort
Danger means loss of God's favor
questions.correctAnswer: God orchestrates circumstances to protect His servants, as seen in the warning and military escort for Paul
questions.explanation: Acts 23:12-24 describes a conspiracy to kill Paul, the warning by his nephew, and the captain’s preparation of a strong escort to keep him safe. This shows God’s care through providential means. See also Acts 23:11 for direct encouragement from the Lord.

questions.question: What can we learn about honesty and integrity from Claudius Lysias’ actions in Acts 23?
options: He investigated the accusations carefully and reported truthfully to the governor
He ignored the accusations and acted on rumors
He sided with the accusers without question
He released Paul without any investigation
questions.correctAnswer: He investigated the accusations carefully and reported truthfully to the governor
questions.explanation: In Acts 23:27-30, Claudius Lysias reports facts about Paul’s case, showing integrity and responsibility in leadership. This models honesty and thoroughness for believers in daily life and work.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to retaliate when wronged. Based on Paul’s response to being struck by the high priest, what biblical principle about forgiveness and restraint can be shared?
options: Paul rebuked the high priest but did not retaliate physically, showing restraint and maintaining conscience before God
Paul struck back immediately
Paul retaliated with harsh words without reason
Paul ignored the offense completely
questions.correctAnswer: Paul rebuked the high priest but did not retaliate physically, showing restraint and maintaining conscience before God
questions.explanation: Acts 23:2-3 records Paul being struck and responding with a verbal rebuke rather than physical retaliation, emphasizing self-control and respect for conscience before God. This teaches believers forgiveness and measured response when mistreated.

questions.question: How does the passage encourage believers to be faithful witnesses even when facing trials?
options: The Lord encourages Paul to bear witness in Rome just as he did in Jerusalem
Believers should hide their faith when persecuted
Faithful witness is optional during trials
Trials mean believers should stop evangelizing
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord encourages Paul to bear witness in Rome just as he did in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Acts 23:11 shows God’s call to Paul to continue his witness despite danger, encouraging believers to persevere in evangelism no matter the circumstances. This highlights obedience and faithfulness in ministry.

questions.question: True or False: In Acts 23, the Sadducees believed in the resurrection of the dead and angels.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 23:8 states that the Sadducees say there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit, which contrasts with the Pharisees’ belief. This shows doctrinal differences important to understand in church teachings.

questions.question: True or False: Paul's nephew played a role in preventing harm to Paul by informing the authorities about the conspiracy.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 23:16-20 describes how Paul's sister's son learned of the plot and warned Paul, who then informed the chief captain, resulting in protective measures. This highlights the value of vigilance and caring within the family of believers.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul said to the council, 'Men and brethren, I have lived in all good ______ before God until this day.'
options: conscience
works
faith
hope
questions.correctAnswer: conscience
questions.explanation: Acts 23:1 shows Paul declaring he has lived in all good conscience before God, emphasizing integrity and a clear conscience as vital for Christian living.

questions.question: What does the conspiracy of more than forty Jews against Paul teach about perseverance and trusting God in the face of opposition?
options: Believers may face severe opposition, but God’s protection and providence prevail
Opposition means failure of faith
Believers should avoid trouble at all costs
Conspiracies are uncommon and not a concern
questions.correctAnswer: Believers may face severe opposition, but God’s protection and providence prevail
questions.explanation: Acts 23:12-15 records a large conspiracy to kill Paul, yet God protected him by revealing the plot and orchestrating his safe transfer. This encourages perseverance and trust in God despite threats.

questions.question: In Acts 23, how is the virtue of obedience modeled by the soldiers and centurions?
options: They promptly follow orders to protect Paul and ensure his safety
They ignore commands and act on their own
They refuse to help Paul
They delay action causing harm
questions.correctAnswer: They promptly follow orders to protect Paul and ensure his safety
questions.explanation: Acts 23:23-31 shows soldiers carrying out the captain’s commands carefully to protect Paul, demonstrating obedience and faithful service, qualities important in daily life and church ministry.

questions.question: What does the interaction between Paul and the council teach about integrity in facing accusations?
options: Paul maintains his innocence and stands firm on truth despite false accusations
Paul admits guilt to avoid trouble
Paul remains silent to escape judgment
Paul changes his testimony to please the council
questions.correctAnswer: Paul maintains his innocence and stands firm on truth despite false accusations
questions.explanation: Acts 23:29 reveals Paul was accused but had nothing worthy of death or bonds, showing his integrity and faithfulness even under pressure. This encourages believers to be honest and upright.

questions.question: How does Acts 23 encourage believers in prayer and spiritual discipline during trials?
options: God’s encouragement to Paul suggests the importance of prayerful reliance on Him for strength
Prayer is irrelevant in trouble
Spiritual discipline should be suspended during trials
Believers should face troubles alone
questions.correctAnswer: God’s encouragement to Paul suggests the importance of prayerful reliance on Him for strength
questions.explanation: Acts 23:11 shows the Lord standing by Paul with encouragement, implying Paul’s close relationship with God through prayer and faith. This teaches believers to rely on God spiritually during hardships.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 23 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 23.

questions.question: What was Paul's declaration before the council that demonstrated his conscience and integrity?
options: I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day
I am innocent of any wrongdoing
I have served the law of Moses faithfully
I am blameless before men
questions.correctAnswer: I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day
questions.explanation: Paul explicitly states this in Acts 23:1, showing his confidence in his conduct before God.

questions.question: Who commanded that Paul be struck on the mouth during the council meeting?
options: The high priest Ananias
Claudius Lysias
The chief captain
One of the Pharisees
questions.correctAnswer: The high priest Ananias
questions.explanation: Acts 23:2 records that it was the high priest Ananias who ordered Paul to be smitten on the mouth.

questions.question: Paul calls the high priest 'thou whited wall' after being struck. This phrase is an example of which literary device?
options: Metaphor
Simile
Alliteration
Hyperbole
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: Paul uses 'whited wall' metaphorically to describe the hypocrisy of the high priest as seen in Acts 23:3.

questions.question: Paul appeals to a scriptural command to justify his initial ignorance of the high priest’s identity. What was this command?
options: Thou shalt not speak evil of the ruler of thy people
Honor thy father and mother
Love thy neighbor as thyself
Thou shalt not kill
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt not speak evil of the ruler of thy people
questions.explanation: In Acts 23:5 Paul references this commandment to explain why he was unaware of the high priest's status.

questions.question: How does Paul strategically divide the council to his advantage?
options: By declaring he is a Pharisee and speaking of the resurrection
By accusing the Sadducees of blasphemy
By appealing to Roman law
By calling for a vote
questions.correctAnswer: By declaring he is a Pharisee and speaking of the resurrection
questions.explanation: Acts 23:6 shows Paul's tactic to create dissension between Pharisees and Sadducees by mentioning resurrection, a disputed topic.

questions.question: Which two groups are in opposition within the council, as revealed in Acts 23?
options: Pharisees and Sadducees
Zealots and Essenes
Romans and Jews
Scribes and Elders
questions.correctAnswer: Pharisees and Sadducees
questions.explanation: Acts 23:7-8 explains the division between Pharisees and Sadducees regarding beliefs about resurrection and spirits.

questions.question: According to Acts 23, what belief distinguishes Pharisees from Sadducees?
options: Pharisees believe in resurrection, angels, and spirits; Sadducees do not
Sadducees believe in resurrection; Pharisees do not
Both believe in resurrection but differ on angels
Neither believe in spirits
questions.correctAnswer: Pharisees believe in resurrection, angels, and spirits; Sadducees do not
questions.explanation: Acts 23:8 states that Sadducees deny resurrection, angels, and spirits, while Pharisees affirm them.

questions.question: What event prompted the chief captain to remove Paul from the council by force?
options: A great dissension and threat of violence
Paul's declaration of innocence
A sudden earthquake
An order from the governor
questions.correctAnswer: A great dissension and threat of violence
questions.explanation: Acts 23:10 describes how the captain feared Paul might be torn apart during the uproar and thus intervened.

questions.question: What assurance did the Lord give to Paul during the night following the council meeting?
options: Be of good cheer, you must also bear witness at Rome
You will be freed soon
Your accusers will be silenced
You will perform miracles
questions.correctAnswer: Be of good cheer, you must also bear witness at Rome
questions.explanation: In Acts 23:11, the Lord encourages Paul that he will testify in Rome as he did in Jerusalem.

questions.question: True or False: More than forty Jews conspired to kill Paul, vowing neither to eat nor drink until their goal was accomplished.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 23:12-13 documents the conspiracy of over forty Jews who bound themselves under a curse to kill Paul.

questions.question: Who alerted Paul to the conspiracy against his life?
options: Paul's sister's son
One of the Pharisees
A Roman centurion
Ananias the high priest
questions.correctAnswer: Paul's sister's son
questions.explanation: Acts 23:16 states that Paul's nephew learned of the plot and informed Paul inside the castle.

questions.question: What does Claudius Lysias do to ensure Paul's safety in response to the conspiracy?
options: He sends a large armed escort to transfer Paul to Caesarea
He imprisons Paul in the castle without trial
He orders Paul's immediate release
He calls a meeting of the council to discuss
questions.correctAnswer: He sends a large armed escort to transfer Paul to Caesarea
questions.explanation: Acts 23:23-24 shows Lysias preparing 200 soldiers, 70 horsemen, and 200 spearmen to safely escort Paul.

questions.question: What is the significance of Lysias' letter to Governor Felix in the context of Roman legal procedures?
options: It explains the legal grounds and protection for Paul's custody
It accuses the Jews of treason
It demands immediate execution of Paul
It requests Felix to ignore the case
questions.correctAnswer: It explains the legal grounds and protection for Paul's custody
questions.explanation: Acts 23:25-30 shows Lysias describing the circumstances and legal status of Paul, emphasizing no charge worthy of death was found.

questions.question: What was Felix’s response upon reading Lysias’ letter and hearing about Paul’s origin?
options: I will hear you when your accusers arrive
You are to be released immediately
You must be sent to Rome at once
You will stand trial before the Sanhedrin
questions.correctAnswer: I will hear you when your accusers arrive
questions.explanation: Acts 23:34-35 records Felix’s decision to hear Paul’s case after the accusers come and to keep him under guard.

questions.question: Which theme in Acts 23 foreshadows Paul's eventual testimony in Rome as prophesied earlier in Scripture?
options: The Lord’s encouragement to Paul to bear witness in Rome
The conspiracy to kill Paul
The division between Pharisees and Sadducees
Lysias’ letter to Felix
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord’s encouragement to Paul to bear witness in Rome
questions.explanation: Acts 23:11 foreshadows Paul's Roman mission, connecting to earlier promises of the Gospel reaching the Gentiles (Acts 1:8).

theological.title: Acts Chapter 23 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 23 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What reason did Paul give for his confident conscience before the council?
options: He had lived in all good conscience before God until this day
He had faithfully preached the Gospel to the Gentiles
He was innocent of any wrongdoing against the Jews
He had been appointed by the apostles in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: He had lived in all good conscience before God until this day
questions.explanation: Paul states his conscience was clear before God, showing his awareness of divine judgment and integrity, as seen in Acts 23:1. This aligns with Psalm 26:1 where David declares a clean heart before God, 1 Timothy 1:5 emphasizing a good conscience, and 2 Corinthians 1:12 where Paul affirms sincerity before God.

questions.question: How did the high priest Ananias respond to Paul's statement before the council?
options: He commanded those standing by to strike Paul on the mouth
He asked Paul to explain his conscience
He dismissed Paul from the council
He called for a vote among the elders
questions.correctAnswer: He commanded those standing by to strike Paul on the mouth
questions.explanation: Ananias ordered Paul to be struck, indicating hostility toward Paul's defense, which Paul rebuked as unlawful in Acts 23:2-3. This reflects the Old Testament respect for priests (Leviticus 19:32) and the New Testament teaching to honor leaders (1 Peter 2:17).

questions.question: What was Paul's response to being struck by command of the high priest?
options: He rebuked Ananias, calling him a whited wall
He remained silent to avoid further conflict
He asked for a lawful trial
He prayed for Ananias
questions.correctAnswer: He rebuked Ananias, calling him a whited wall
questions.explanation: Paul confronted the high priest, calling him a 'whited wall' for hypocrisy and unlawful judgment (Acts 23:3). His defense shows the principle of lawful authority and justice as taught in Romans 13:1-4 and Exodus 22:28.

questions.question: What doctrinal difference caused dissension in the council after Paul's declaration of his beliefs?
options: The resurrection of the dead
The observance of the Mosaic Law
The divinity of Christ
The role of the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: The resurrection of the dead
questions.explanation: Paul identified himself as a Pharisee, affirming belief in the resurrection, which caused division with the Sadducees who denied it (Acts 23:6-8). This reflects the biblical teaching on resurrection in Daniel 12:2, John 11:25, and 1 Corinthians 15:12-14.

questions.question: According to Acts 23, what do the Sadducees deny?
options: Resurrection, angels, and spirits
The existence of God
The coming of the Messiah
The authority of the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Resurrection, angels, and spirits
questions.explanation: Sadducees deny resurrection and spiritual beings, contrasting with Pharisees who confess them (Acts 23:8). This denial conflicts with scriptures affirming angels (Hebrews 1:14), spirits (Ecclesiastes 12:7), and resurrection (Isaiah 26:19).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the Pharisees when Paul mentioned the resurrection and spirits?
options: They defended Paul, saying if a spirit or angel spoke to him, they should not fight against God
They accused Paul of blasphemy
They called for Paul's immediate execution
They remained silent out of fear
questions.correctAnswer: They defended Paul, saying if a spirit or angel spoke to him, they should not fight against God
questions.explanation: The Pharisees supported Paul, indicating openness to divine revelation through spirits or angels (Acts 23:9). This aligns with Old Testament accounts of angelic messages (Genesis 18:1-2), and New Testament affirmations of angelic ministry (Luke 1:26-38).

questions.question: What divine encouragement did the Lord give Paul during the night following the dissension?
options: "Be of good cheer, Paul: for as thou hast testified of me in Jerusalem, so must thou bear witness also at Rome"
"Do not fear, for I will rescue you"
"Your suffering will end soon"
"The council will release you"
questions.correctAnswer: "Be of good cheer, Paul: for as thou hast testified of me in Jerusalem, so must thou bear witness also at Rome"
questions.explanation: God encouraged Paul to remain steadfast in his witness, promising the mission to Rome (Acts 23:11). This divine commissioning echoes Jesus' commands in Matthew 28:19-20 and the promise of the Spirit's power in Acts 1:8.

questions.question: What was the nature of the conspiracy formed by certain Jews against Paul?
options: They bound themselves under a curse not to eat or drink until they killed Paul
They planned to imprison Paul secretly
They plotted to send Paul to a distant land
They intended to silence Paul by bribes
questions.correctAnswer: They bound themselves under a curse not to eat or drink until they killed Paul
questions.explanation: More than forty Jews made a solemn vow to kill Paul, demonstrating the seriousness of their hatred (Acts 23:12-14). This mirrors Old Testament examples of binding oaths under curses (Joshua 9:15; 1 Kings 21:7) and highlights human sinfulness and enmity toward the gospel.

questions.question: Who informed Paul of the plot to kill him, and how did Paul respond?
options: Paul's sister's son informed him; Paul sent him to the chief captain
One of the Pharisees warned Paul; Paul fled immediately
A Roman soldier overheard; Paul confronted the conspirators
A fellow prisoner told Paul; Paul prayed for deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: Paul's sister's son informed him; Paul sent him to the chief captain
questions.explanation: Paul's nephew heard the conspiracy and informed Paul, who then sent him to the commander to reveal the plot (Acts 23:16-18). This episode shows God's providential protection and the wisdom of prudent action, consistent with Proverbs 11:14 and Romans 8:28.

questions.question: How did the chief captain respond upon learning of the conspiracy against Paul?
options: He arranged a large military escort to transport Paul safely to Caesarea
He dismissed the warning as a rumor
He imprisoned Paul in the castle without further action
He released Paul to the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: He arranged a large military escort to transport Paul safely to Caesarea
questions.explanation: To protect Paul, Claudius Lysias sent 470 soldiers, horsemen, and spearmen to escort Paul to Felix the governor (Acts 23:23-24). This reflects the Roman authority's recognition of Paul's citizenship and the seriousness of threats against him, paralleling other biblical examples of divine protection (Psalm 91:11-12).

questions.question: What was the content of the letter Claudius Lysias wrote to Governor Felix concerning Paul?
options: Paul was seized by Jews who wanted to kill him; Lysias rescued him because Paul was a Roman citizen
Paul had committed crimes against the Roman Empire
Paul was preaching sedition and rebellion
Paul voluntarily surrendered to Roman authorities
questions.correctAnswer: Paul was seized by Jews who wanted to kill him; Lysias rescued him because Paul was a Roman citizen
questions.explanation: Lysias explained the circumstances leading to Paul's arrest and rescue due to his Roman citizenship (Acts 23:26-27). This underscores the importance of Roman legal rights and God's providential use of secular authority for Paul's mission, as also seen in Acts 22:25-29 and Romans 13:1-7.

questions.question: What accusation did Lysias find against Paul when he examined the charges before the Jewish council?
options: Paul was accused on questions of their law but had nothing worthy of death or bonds
Paul was charged with blasphemy against God
Paul was accused of inciting rebellion
Paul was charged with theft and robbery
questions.correctAnswer: Paul was accused on questions of their law but had nothing worthy of death or bonds
questions.explanation: Lysias noted no charge meriting death or imprisonment against Paul, illustrating the injustice of the accusations (Acts 23:29). This reflects the biblical principle of fair judgment (Deuteronomy 16:18-20) and Jesus’ innocence before unjust trials (Isaiah 53:9).

questions.question: Where was Paul kept after arriving in Caesarea, and what was the governor's decision regarding his hearing?
options: Paul was kept in Herod's judgment hall; the governor would hear him when his accusers arrived
Paul was immediately released without trial
Paul was imprisoned in a common jail indefinitely
Paul was transferred to Jerusalem for trial
questions.correctAnswer: Paul was kept in Herod's judgment hall; the governor would hear him when his accusers arrived
questions.explanation: Governor Felix ordered Paul detained in Herod's judgment hall until his accusers came forward (Acts 23:34-35). This shows the Roman legal process and God's sovereignty in Paul's journey, consistent with Acts 24:1-2 and Paul's appeal to Caesar in Acts 25:11.

questions.question: What was Paul's self-identification that sparked division among the council members?
options: I am a Pharisee, the son of a Pharisee, and on the hope of the resurrection of the dead
I am a Sadducee, rejecting resurrection and spirits
I am a Roman citizen appointed by Caesar
I am a follower of Jesus of Nazareth
questions.correctAnswer: I am a Pharisee, the son of a Pharisee, and on the hope of the resurrection of the dead
questions.explanation: Paul declared his Pharisaic heritage and belief in the resurrection, causing a split between Pharisees and Sadducees (Acts 23:6-7). This confession highlights core Christian doctrines of resurrection (1 Corinthians 15:20-22) and the continuity of faith from Judaism to Christianity (Romans 11:16-17).

questions.question: What does Paul's experience in Acts 23 reveal about God's providence in the face of human opposition?
options: God protects and encourages His servants even amid plots and trials
God allows His servants to be destroyed without intervention
Success depends solely on human effort and alliances
Divine intervention is only visible through miracles
questions.correctAnswer: God protects and encourages His servants even amid plots and trials
questions.explanation: The Lord's reassurance to Paul, the warning of the conspiracy, and the military escort show God's providential care (Acts 23:11-24). This reflects biblical themes of divine protection (Psalm 34:7), encouragement in suffering (2 Corinthians 12:9), and God's sovereignty over human plans (Proverbs 16:9).
